vi_translation: Now every morning when I wake up, I look out the window of my room to see if there are any signs that someone is in Margo's room. She usually lowers the bamboo blinds, but since Margo hasn't been home, her mother or someone else has pulled the blinds up, so I can see a patch of blue wall and a white ceiling. That Saturday morning, Margo had only been missing for forty-eight hours, so I guessed she probably wouldn't be back right away. Even so, I still felt a bit of disappointment when I saw the neatly rolled-up bamboo blinds.
tr_translation: Now, every morning, I would look out of my window to check if there was any sign of life in Margo's room. She always kept her bamboo blinds closed, but after she left, her mother or someone else had opened them, so I could see a small piece of the blue wall and the white ceiling. That Saturday morning, forty-eight hours after she had left, I had calculated that she had not yet returned home, but still felt a twinge of disappointment when I saw that the blinds were still open.

Kapa mohlomong lilemo tse tharo kapa tse 'ne ho tloha joale, kapa matsatsi a mararo ho tloha joale, meea e hlolang e nka ballon hae, hobane e hloka chelete, kapa e hlaphohetsoe, kapa e fetoa ke mor'abo lona. Empa mamelang, nyana ena, khoele e tla fokotseha ka linako tsohle. "

tn: Ntshekegele tsebe, wena morwa. Se se diregang ke gore, ka dinako tse dingwe, motho yo o rileng o na le moya o o sa siamang, o ka se kgone go dira gore batsadi ba gagwe ba nne le moya o montle. Bana ba, ba tshwana le di-helium tsa di-helium. Ba a bofa ka go lesola, mme morago ga moo go tla bo go na le sengwe se se sa tsamayeng sentle, mme ba se ka ba latlha fela. O ka nna wa se tlhole o bona theke. E ne e le kwa canada kgotsa kwa canada, e ya go direla kwa hoteleng, mme pele ga go itsese, e ntse e le go ja kofi e e ntseng jalo mo dijong tse di tshwanang le tse dingwe tse di utlwisang botlhoko ka dingwaga di le 30. 13-40 Jwale, ka tsatsi le leng le le leng le le leng, ho tloha ka nako eo, kapa matsatsi a mararo a mararo kapa a mane, ho tloha ka nako eo, ho ya ka mengwaha ya hae, kapa e le nngwe ya tsona. "A ko o utlwe, mosimane yole o tla mo yingwa."

mg: Henoy, Zanako Izao no mitranga: misy olonaâ€”ankizivavy matetikaâ€” manana toe-tsaina malalaka, tsy dia tsara loatra amin'ny ray aman-dreniny. Ireo ankizy ireo, toy ny balaonina mifatotra izy ireo. Mihenjana amin'ilay tady izy ireo ary mihenjana amin'izany, ary avy eo misy zavatra mitranga, ary tapaka izany tady izany, ary mitsingevana fotsiny izy ireo. Ary angamba tsy hahita ilay baolina intsony ianao. Mipetraka any Kanada na any amin'ny toerana sasany izy io, mahazo asa ao amin'ny trano fisakafoanana iray, ary alohan'ny hahatsikaritry ny balaonina, dia efa nandrotsaka kafe tao amin'io toeram-pisakafoanana io ihany izy ho an'ireo mpivaro-tena mampalahelo nandritra ny telopolo taona. Na mety ho telo na efa-taona aty aoriana, na telo na efatra andro manomboka izao, dia entin'ny rivotra manjaka any an-trano ilay balaonina, satria mila vola izy, na mivonto, na malahelo ny zandriny lahy. Fa henoy, anaka, tapaka foana izany tady izany."

en: Talking like this to her kept me calm, strangely. It kept me from imagining the possibilities. I came again to the sagging wooden sign for Grovepoint Acres. I could almost hear the sighs of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the dead-end asphalt road. It looked like a driveway without a house. I left RHAPAW running and got out. From close up, I could see that Grovepoint Acres was more finished than it initially appeared. Two dirt roads ending in cul-de-sacs had been cut into the dusty ground, although the roads had eroded so much I could barely see their outlines. As I walked up and down both streets, I could feel the heat in my nose with each breath. The scalding sun made it hard to move, but I knew the beautiful, if morbid, truth: heat made death reek, and Grovepoint Acres smelled like nothing except cooked air and car exhaustâ€”our cumulative exhalations held close to the surface by the humidity.

Ke ne ka boela kwa go hudugela kwa morago ga go bona gore go ne go na le ditshupa tse di neng di le kwa godimo tsa 1000. Ke ne ke kgÃ´na go utlwa fa ke ne ke le mo tseleng e e neng e le teng fa ke ne ke le mo tseleng e e neng e le teng. E ne e kete ke tsela e e senang legae. I'm Gone Ridin' And Gone Go tswa foo, ke ne ke kgona go lemoga gore go ne go na le dilo tse dingwe tse di neng di le gaufi le go feta fa go ne go lebega go ne go na le tsone. Go ne go na le ditsela di le pedi tse di rurufetseng tse di neng di le mo mmung, le fa go ne go na le ditsela tse dintsi tse di neng di sa kgone go di bona. Fa ke ntse ke tsamaya ka dinao le mo mebileng, ke ne ke kgona go bona mogote mo nkong ya me ka phefumoloho nngwe le nngwe. Letsatsi le ne la dira gore go nne thata go tsamaya, mme ke ne ke itse bontle, fa ke ne ke utlwa botlhoko, boammaaruri: mogote o ne wa dira gore go nne le loso, le diheketara tsa Grovepoint di ne di nkga jaaka go se na sepe fa se se apeilwe ke phefo le koloi e e neng e apesitswe ka tsela e e feteletseng e e neng e tshwerwe ke metsi.

vi_translation: Unlike previous ghost towns, Quail Hollow has someone looking after it. No houses have been built yet, but the lots are marked with boundary stakes, and the grass has been freshly cut. The streets in this area are paved and properly named. In the center of the subdivision, a perfectly round lake has been dug, but for some reason, no water has been led into it yet. Driving by, I estimated the lake to be about three meters deep, with a diameter of over a hundred meters. A rubber pipe runs windingly inside the lake, connected to the center, where a fountain made of aluminum and steel is erected from the bottom up to eye level. I was glad the lake was dry, meaning I didn't have to stare at the water, wondering if Margo was at the bottom, waiting for me to dive in and find her.
